Aus dem englischen stammender Begriff für Randstein. Im Rennsport werden die meist farbig abgesetzten und mehr oder weniger flachen Randsteine so genannt, die den Pistenrand vor allem in Kurven markieren.

Aus dem Französischen stammende Bezeichnung für die einschalige Bauweise der Fahrerzelle eine Formel-1-Rennwagens. In den Anfängen dieser Bauweise wurden diese Fahrerzellen aus Leichtmetall gefertigt. Heute bestehen sie aus Kevlar, Kohlefasern und anderen Verbundstoffen.

Ausgleichsgetriebe, das zwischen die Antriebsräder geschaltet wird, um die unterschiedlichen Radumdrehungen beim Kurvenfahren auszugleichen. Dies ist nötig, weil in einer Kurve das äussere Rad eine größere Strecke zurücklegen, und sich daher schneller als das kurveninnere Rad drehen muss.

Bei seinem Grand Prix Sieg 1963 in Monaco war sein Sprössling erst 2 Jahre alt. Seine Frau Bette umsorgte sich mütterlich um die beiden. Wer sah aus wie sein eigenes Denkmal am Ende seiner Formel 1 Laufbahn (ganzer Name)?
Bezeichnung für die Abnutzung der Reifenoberfläche beim Fahren. Wird von Jahr zu Jahr wichtiger für die Renntaktik und die Rennstrategie.
Bezeichnung für windabweisende aerodynamische Hilfsmittel . Unterschieden wird zwischen Front-, Seiten- und Heck·······
Das kontrollierte seitliche Rutschen eines Rennwagens bei Kurvenfahrten wird im Ralleysport weitaus öfter eingesetzt als beim Grand - Prix - Sport.
Der ············ ? ist eine Vorrichtung, die das Chassis daran hindern soll, sich über die Längsachse unnötig zu bewegen.
Der ············· ? ist im Rennsport jener Punkt einer Kurve, an dem die Ideallinie den Kurvenradius berührt.

Der Gradmesser für die Durchzugskraft eines Motors, seine Elastizität und das Beschleunigungsvermögen im Auto. Basis ist der Verbrennungsdruck im Motor, der über die Kolben und Pleuel auf die Kurbelwelle wirkt. Am effektivsten ist er, wenn der Füllungsgrad optimal und die Verbrennung am wirksamsten ist. Dies ist nicht bei der Höchstdrehzahl der Fall, sondern darunter.
Die ·········· ? ist dafür verantwortlich, dass ein Auto in einer Kurve nach aussen gedrängt wird. Sie wirkt, wenn Materie ihre Bewegungsrichtung ändert.

Die ·············· ? sichern die Rennstrecken gegen uneinsichtige Zuschauer ab, zeigen den Fahrern mit den Flaggensignalen Gefahren an, schieben defekte Rennwagen von der Strecke und helfen bei der Rettung verletzter Fahrer. Im englischen Sprachgebrauch werden sie auch Stewards genannt.

Dies ist das Abkommen, das die FIA und die FOCA Anfang der 80er Jahre schlossen. Vorausgegangen war ein Streit zwischen dem Weltverband des Motorsports und der Formel - 1 - Konstrukteursvereinigung, der beinahe das Ende der Formel 1 bedeutet hätte. Man einigte sich auf eine Regelung, bei der alle Formel - 1 - Teams gemeinsam bei bestimmten Regeländerungen zustimmen müssen. (englisch)
Diese auch im Bau von normalen Serienwagen verwendete Form der tragenden Teile der Radaufhängung werden so bezeichnet, weil sie in der Draufsicht dreieckig aussehen.
Diese Einlassöffnung oberhalb der Fahrerhelme soll möglichst viel Luft zum Motor im Wagenheck führen, um diesen - vor allem bei langen Vollgasstrecken - zu kühlen.

Diese französische Bezeichnung ist international für einen abgesperrten Platz neben einer Rennstrecke gebräuchlich, auf dem nach einem Rennen die drei erstplatzierten Wagen abgestellt werden müssen. Niemandem ist es ohne besondere Genehmigung erlaubt, sich den dort abgestellten Wagen zu nähern. So kann die Technische Kommission jederzeit die Siegerwagen kontrollieren, wenn irgendwelche Proteste auftreten.
Dieser auch Ground-Effect genannte Effekt soll den Rennwagen auf der Piste nach unten ziehen, also ansaugen, um die Kurvengeschwindigkeit somit zu erhöhen.

Dieser vor den Boxen liegende Fahrbahnteil ist zur Rennstrecke hin abgesperrt. Hier wird während des Trainings und Rennens an den Wagen gearbeitet. Während des Trainings gilt hier ein Tempolimit von "120 km/h" und während des Rennens eine Geschwingkeitsbegrenzung von "100 km/h". Wird diese überschritten, drohen den Fahrern Geldstrafen.

Ein ········· ? ist das Anhalten eines Rennwagens im Rennverlauf, um die Reifen zu wechseln, aufzutanken, oder kleinere Mängel zu beseitigen. Seit die Nachtankung wieder erlaubt wurde, hat der ········· ? eine besondere Bedeutung bekommen. Er ist wichtiger Bestandteil der Renntaktik.
Frei übersetzt bedeutet dieser englische Begriff Fehlfeuer. Gemeint sind damit Fehlzündungen des Motors, die zu Aussetzern führen.
Für welchen Automobil-Konzern gewann John Surtees mit einem V12 Zylinder-Motor den Grand Prix von Italien in Monza 1967?

Hiermit ist die Fähigkeit gemeint, die Kraft des Motors auf die Fahrbahn zu übertragen. Bei mechanischem ···· ? ist das Chassis in seiner Gesamtkonstruktion und dann die Haftfähigkeit der Reifen gemeint. Aerodynamischen ···· ? nennt man den Abtrieb.
Immer wenn seine Formel 1 Wagen als Erste über die Ziellinie eines Grand Prix gefahren sind, warf er seinen Hut auf die Rennstrecke. Wer war diese Formel 1 Legende?

In der Kaderschmiede Eton erzogen, bringt er einen Hauch von Wohlerzogenheit in die Formel 1 Szene, und das nicht nur, weil er aus der britischen Bier-Dynastie dieses Namans stammt. Um welchen Piloten handelt es sich?
In welchem Jahr wurde McLaren das erste mal Constructors Champion?
International verwendeter Begriff für Boxengasse (englisch) ?
Internationale Anzeige für die Werkstatt neben einer Rennstrecke, in denen ein Team seine Wagen unterbringt, wartet, repariert und umfassend betreut.
Italienischer begriff, für einsitzige, offene Rennwagen, mit freistehenden Rädern?

Mit dem ·········· ? wird die Luft komprimiert, die dem Verbrennungsraum des Motors zugeführt wird. In den 80ern erreichten die Techniker so PS-Zahlen von über 1100, bis eine Reglementsänderung diese verbot.

Mit Einführung der ··········· ? in den Rennsport hat sich die Sicherheit sowohl für Fahrer als auch für die Zuschauer wesentlich erhöht. In den Anfängen der Formel 1 wurden Bäume, Mauern oder andere Hindernisse oft nur mit wenigen Strohballen abgedeckt. Heute werden auf allen Rennstrecken speziell entwickelte ··········· ? montiert, die auch einem Aufprall von 300 km/h standhalten.
Mit welchem Formel 1 Wagen gewann der Australier Jack Brabham 1959 die Weltmeisterschaft?

Sein Lebensweg von Mainz nach Monza ist kurz gewesen, nur gerade 28 Jahre. Zwei Monate nach seinem Tod wurde er Formel 1 Weltmeister. Wer war dieser Pilot, dessen Tochter Natasha und dessen Frau Nina hiess?

Seit den Anfängen der Formel 1 weiss man, dass das Wetter rennentscheidend sein kann. In den Anfangsjahren, als die Rennreifen noch schmal und profiliert waren, war das Aquaplaningproblem noch nicht so gross. Mit zunehmender Reifenbreite und Einführung der Slicks wurden die Wagen immer unkontrollierbarer, was dazu führte, das die Reifenhersteller zusätzlich auch ··········· ? entwickelten, mit denen es immer noch möglich ist, weitgehend kontrollierbar zu fahren.
So nennt man in Italien normalerweise einen kleinen Esel. In der Formel 1 wird so der Ersatzwagen genannt, der vor allem bei Tests herangezogen wird.

So werden enge Kurven genannt, die von den Rennveranstaltern auf geraden Strecken angelegt werden, um Fahrer dazu zu zwingen, die Geschwindigkeit zu reduzieren. Oftmals werden ········· ? aber erst angelgt, nachdem die Strecke an diesen Stellen zu schnell befahren werden konnte und damit die Sicherheit der Fahrer nicht mehr gewährleistet war.

Stromaggregat im Auto, das meisst von einem Keilriemen angetrieben wird, und für den nötigen Strom sorgt. Im Rennsport wurde oft auf eine ············· ? verzichtet. Man musste den Strombedarf mit kleinen Batterien und Akkus decken.

Um auf der Nordschleife am Ring schnell zu sein, muss man 1967 grosse Sprünge machen. Er war Meister dieses Fachs. Allein zwei Grand Prix gewinnt er 1969 auf Brabham und 1972 auf Ferrari auf der Nordschleife. Wer machte diese 15-Meter-Sprünge?

(Arthropoden), artenreicher Unterstamm der Gliedertiere, umfasst Krebse, Spinnentiere, Milben, Schwertschwänze, Tausendfüsser und Insekten; getrenntgeschlechtliche Tiere mit paarigen, je nach Körperregion verschieden ausgebildeten segmentalen Gliedmassen, die von einem Chitinpanzer umgeben sind.
(Artikulaten), zusammenfassende Bezeichnung für Gliederfüsser und Ringelwürmer; gemeinsames Merkmal ist ein in hintereinander liegende Abschnitte gegliederter Körper.
(Aye-Aye), eichhörnchenartiger Halbaffe Madagaskars, der verlängerte 3. Finger dient zum Klettern, Nachttier.

(Cerebrum), von Häuten und knöcherner Schädelkapsel umschlossener Teil des Zentralnervensystems; Hauptabschnitte: Gross····, Klein···· und ····stamm, der die beiden untereinander und mit dem Rückenmark verbindet.

(Chlorophyzeen), chlorophyllhaltige, häufig fadenförmige Algen; weit verbreitet in Süss-, Brack- und Meerwasser sowie in und auf dem Boden, zum Teil als Flechten oder gemeinsam mit Pilzen lebend; u. a. Volvox, Chlorella, Armleuchteralge.
(Cutis), den Körper umhüllende Deckschicht, grösstes Organ mit vielfältigen Aufgaben.
(Dompfaff, Blutfink), schwarz-grauer Finkenvogel, Männchen rotbäuchig; in Eurasien.
(Ephemeriden), 1-6 Zentimeter lange Geradflügler, die keine Nahrung aufnehmen, extrem kurzlebig; Larven leben 1-3 Jahre im Wasser.
(Flagellum), Körperanhang; langer, beweglicher Plasmafaden, der männlichen Keimzellen und manchen Einzellern zur Fortbewegung dient.
(Flugechsen), fliegende Reptilien des Mesozoikums. Flughaut zwischen stark verlängertem Finger und Körperflanke, bis 8 m Flügelspannweite, behaarter Rumpf; zahlreiche Formen.
(Genetten), helle, marderähnliche Schleichkatzen mit dunklen Flecken. Nordafrikanische ············· (Nordafrika, Südwesteuropa), Kleinfleckige ············· (West- und Zentralafrika).
(Grauwerk), grau meliertes Winterfell des sibirischen Eichhörnchens.

(griechisch für "Armechse"): Bis 27 Meter langer, pflanzenfressender Riesensaurier der ausgehenden Jura-Zeit, nur unwesentlich kleiner als Diplodocus, doch mit über 50 Tonnen Gewicht (einige Forscher nehmen sogar das Doppelte an) weitaus schwerer und damit das mächtigste Landtier der Erdgeschichte.
(Grunzochse), langhaariges, schwarzes Wildrind der zentralasiatischen Hochländer (vor allem Tibet); als Hausrind und Lasttier liefert es Milch, Fleisch und Fell, der Kot dient als Brennmaterial.

(Hakenwurm), ca. 1 Zentimeter langer Fadenwurm, schmarotzt im Dünndarm des Menschen (frisst Darmzotten); Eier entwickeln sich ausserhalb des Wirts nur in grösseren Tiefen, daher früher besonders bei Bergarbeitern aufgetreten. Erreger der Ankylostomiasis.

(Handflügler), dichtbehaarte, nachtaktive Säugetiere mit kräftigem Gebiss und grosser, besonders gut durchbluteter, nackter Flughaut (Hautfalte) zwischen den stark verlängerten Mittelhandknochen, Fingern und dem Schwanz. Ausgezeichnete Flieger, die sich mit Ultraschall orientieren, nützliche Insektenvertilger; die Vampire sind Tollwutüberträger. Heimische Arten durch Insektizide und Holzschutzmittel stark gefährdet, zum Beispiel Mausohr, Kleine Hufeisennase, Abendsegler. Flughunde.
(Jagdleopard), schnellstes Säugetier (bis 110 Stundenkilometer), schwarz-gelbgefleckte, hochbeinige Grosskatze mit kleinem Kopf; früher zur Antilopenjagd abgerichtet; in Afrika und Indien.
(Mesenterium), gekräuselte Bauchfellfalte zur Aufhängung von Bauchorganen (zum Beispiel Darm, Magen, Hoden); enthält Blut- und Lymphgefässe und Nieren zur Organversorgung.

(Nematoden), artenreiche Hohlwurmklasse; fadenförmige, wimperlose Rundwürmer mit Saugorgan; mikroskopisch klein bis 1 m lang; zahlreiche Parasiten bei Pflanze, Tier und Mensch, zum Beispiel Älchen, Gruben-, Madenwurm, Trichinen.
(Orthopteren), Insekten mit beissenden Mundwerkzeugen, lederartigen Vorder- und häutigen Hinterflügeln, zum Beispiel Ohrwürmer, Schaben, Fang-, Gespenst- u. a. Heuschrecken.

(Pteromyidae), mit etwa 40 Arten in Nordosteuropa und Asien sowie 2 Arten in Nordamerika verbreitete Unterfamilie der Hörnchen. Die zwischen 6 und 60 cm langen ·········· haben zwischen den Vordergliedmassen und den Fusswurzeln eine behaarte Flughaut, die sie beim Sprung fallschirmartig spannen und so über grössere Distanzen (bis 50 m) gleiten, weswegen sie auch Gleithörnchen genannt werden. Beim Flug steuern sie mit ihrem breiten, buschigen, körperlangen Schwanz.
(Renken), lachsartige Speisefische in Flüssen und Seen Nordeuropas und der Alpen, zum Beispiel der Blau·······
(Riesenscholle), bis 2 Meter langer Plattfisch der nördlichen Meere.

(russ. Beluga), bis 9 Meter langer Störfisch mit dreieckiger Schnauze; Rogen wird als echter Kaviar gehandelt; Schwarzes und Kaspisches Meer. ······(?)blase, innere, aus Glutin bestehende Schicht der Schwimmblase von Stör, Wels u. a., wird zum Schönen des Weines oder zur Herstellung von Leim verwendet.
(Schamlaus), 1-3 mm lange Menschenlaus; bohrt sich mit ihrem Kopf tief in behaarte Haut ein (ausser Kopfhaut).

(Uterus), im Beckenraum gelegenes birnenförmiges, muskulöses Hohlorgan der Frau und weiblicher Säugetiere, in dem sich bei eintretender Schwangerschaft der Fetus bzw. Embryo entwickelt. Sie ist mit einer Schleimhaut ausgekleidet und besteht aus dem ············körper, von dem die Eileiter abgehen, und dem ··········hals, der mit einer kleinen Öffnung, dem Muttermund, in die Scheide mündet.
········· (?) starren während schwerer Regenfälle oft in den Himmel - und ertrinken.

0,2 Millimeter grosse Spinnentiere, stechen Pflanzenteile an, verflüssigen Inhalt der Zellen und saugen ihn aus. Die Pflanze reagiert darauf mit abnormem Zellwachstum (zum Beispiel Gallen). Bevorzugt an Birnbäumen (Pockenkrankheit).
1 Millimeter langes, schwarz behaartes, flügelloses Urinsekt aus der Ordnung der Springschwänze; auf alpinen Gletschern.

1. Schnecken mit flügelartig ausgedehnter Gehäusemündung, zum Beispiel Pelikanfuss; 2. Flossenfüsser, Hochseemeeresschnecken, meist ohne Schale, Hinterkiemer (Opisthobranchia); frei umherschwimmend, indem sie mit seitlichen Lappen des Fusses wie mit Flügeln oder Flossen schlagen.
11-18 mm lange, rotäugige Aasfliegen; lebendgebärend, legen ihre Maden in rohes Fleisch.
2 bis 2,5 mm lang, bernsteinfarben; verursacht Frass an eiweiss- und zuckerhaltigen Stoffen; grosser Krankheitsüberträger.
Als Alaskabär grösstes Landraubtier; Sohlengänger, Allesfresser, guter Kletterer und Schwimmer; hält keinen eigentlichen Winterschlaf. Lässt sich mit dem Eisbären kreuzen.
Altertümliche, eierlegende australische Säugetiere. Einzige Vertreter: Ameisenigel und Schnabeltier.
Aus Wildformen durch künstliche Auslese und Zucht (Domestikation) vom Menschen gehaltene Tiere; zu den ältesten zählt der Hund, nicht viel später wurde die Katze domestiziert.
Bei welcher "Pferdeart" trägt das Männchen die ungeborenen Kinder aus?
Bis 1,5 Meter langer räuberischer Knochenfisch, Speisefisch; im Süsswasser Europas, Asiens und Nordamerikas beheimatet.
Bis 3000 kg schweres afrikanisches Säugetier; amphibischer Pflanzenfresser, der rudelweise in Flüssen und Seen lebt; Männchen mit gewaltigen Hauern (Eckzähne). Zwerg········ in Westafrika.
Ca. 30 cm lange, baumbewohnende Agamen; können mit aufstellbaren Hautfalten von Baum zu Baum gleiten. Vorkommen: Südostasien.

Circa 30 Zentimeter lange Knochenfische der nördlichen Meere mit vielen örtlichen Abarten und Rassen; Planktonfresser mit tief gegabelter Schwanzflosse, die Schwimmblase fehlt. Wandern zur Laichzeit in grossen Schwärmen zu bestimmten Laichplätzen; Speisefisch. Im Handel zum Beispiel als Salz······(?), Bückling (geräuchert), Rollmops (in Essig eingelegt) oder Matjeshering (noch nicht geschlechtsreifer ······(?)).
Das Kapschaf ist kein Schaf, sondern ein ·····?

Räuberische Knorpelfische; Kopf spitz auslaufend, Maul unterständig mit scharfen Zähnen, die nur zum Reissen, nicht zum Kauen dienen. Viele Arten lebendgebärend; 50 Zentimeter (Katzen···· (?)) bis 15 Meter (Raub···· (?)) lang. Blau···· (?), Weiss···· (?), Wal····(?), Hammer····(?), Dorn····(?) u. a., in allen Meeren verbreitet.

Sammelbezeichnung für die Schnabelsaurier, die sich durch seltsame Helme, Hörner und Buckel auf dem Kopf auszeichneten und mit ihrem schnabelartig verhornten Maul Pflanzen abrissen, u. a. Lambeosaurus, Parasaurolophus.

Stammt vom indischen Bankivahuhn ab, das vermutlich vor 4 Jahrtausenden domestiziert wurde; heute etwa 150 Rassen; Fleisch-, Lege- oder Zierhühner.

Zweiflügler, ohne Mücken; Larven sind fusslose Maden mit reduzierter Kopfkapsel. Zu den Spaltschlüpfern (verlassen Puppe durch Längsspalt) gehören Bremsen, Raub-, Tanz- und Hummel······. Zu den Deckelschlüpfern (verlassen Puppe durch deckelähnliche Öffnung) gehören die Echten ·······, Buckel-, Schweb-, Dickkopf·······. Echte ·······: Dung-, Blumen-, Stech-, Raupen-, Dassel-······, Rachen- und Nasenbremsen.

Zwischen 25-60 Zentimeter grosser Greifvogel, Weibchen bussardgross, Männchen kleiner; schlägt Vögel und Kleinsäuger, mit rund 50 Arten fast über ganz Europa verbreitet, zum Beispiel Hühner······· und Sperber.

zwischen 5 und 30 Zentimeter langes, zu den Mäusen gehörendes Säugetier. Nagetier mit grossen Backentaschen für den Nahrungstransport in den Erdbau; Winterschläfer; Gemeiner ······· aus den asiatischen Steppen eingewandert; Gold······· stammt von einer rötlichen Wildform Syriens ab.
··············· (?) kratzen sich mit Stöckchen hinter den Ohren.
(Blaubeere, Bickbeere), Heidekrautgewächs; niedrige Waldsträucher mit blauschwarzen, essbaren Beeren.
(Cerealien), verschiedene wegen ihrer Körnerfrüchte als Kulturpflanzen genutzte Gräser; Weizen, Reis, Mais, Hafer, Roggen, Gerste und Hirse; viele Zuchtsorten.
(Chinarindenbaum), Rötegewächs; tropischer Baum, liefert die Chinarinde.

(Digitalis), Gattung der Familie der Rachenblütler; giftige Staudengewächse mit in langen Trauben angeordneten, glockenförmigen Blüten. Die Blätter des Roten, Gelben und Wolligen ········· enthalten herzwirksame Glykoside.

(Ficus), Gattung der Familie der Maulbeergewächse; viele tropische Arten, zum Teil Zierpflanzen (Gummibaum). Als Essfeige (Echte Feige) wichtige Kulturpflanze der Mittelmeerländer. Milchsaft der meisten Arten liefert Kautschuk.
(Flatterhirse), in Laubwäldern verbreitete hohe Gräser; Futterpflanze.

(Lein), Gattung der Familie der Leingewächse; einjährige, sehr alte Kulturpflanze, als Faserpflanze zur Herstellung von Leinengewebe und als Ölfrucht zur Gewinnung des Leinöls aus den Samen kultiviert. Samen······ wird vor allem in Südeuropa, Faser······ vor allem in Nordeuropa angebaut.
(Massliebchen), artenarme Gattung der Familie Korbblütler, auf Wiesen und Parkrasen; in Gärten als Tausendschön kultiviert.
(Opuntie), artenreiche Kakteengattung mit blattförmig abgeflachten Sprossgliedern; Echter ············(?) oder Feigenopuntie mit essbaren Früchten, häufig im Mittelmeerraum.
(Rapunzel), Baldriangewächs; gärtnerische Nutzpflanze. Blattrosette als Salat.

(Stipa), in den Steppen und Wüsten auf allen Kontinenten heimische Gattung der Süssgräser mit etwa 250 Arten. Die meisten Arten sind hochwachsende, trockenrasenbildende Pflanzen mit langen Grannen für die Windverbreitung. Wegen ihrer Vorliebe für trockene Böden kommen in Mitteleuropa nur zwei Arten wildwachsend vor, die auf sonnigen Hängen zum Beispiel in den Weinbaugebieten oder auf Kalkfelsen gedeihen: das Echte Feldgras (Stipa pennata) mit fedrigen Grannen von über 30 cm Länge und das Haarpfriemengras (Stipa capillata) mit glatten und etwas kürzern Grannen. Beide Arten stehen unter Naturschutz.
(Taxus), zweihäusiges Nadelgehölz mit weichen, spitzen Blättern; in allen Teilen, ausgenommen dem roten, fleischigen Samenmantel, giftig. Hartes, harzloses Holz.
(Zitterpappel), Weidengewächs, bis 30 Meter hoher Baum mit hängenden, runden Blättern.
Gattung der Familie der ··········(?)gewächse; Gemeines ··········(?), Honig- und Weidepflanze auf mageren Böden. Pflanze nordwestdeutscher Heideflächen.
Gattung der Familie der Dickblattgewächse; Stauden mit fleischigen Blättern, meist in Rosetten. Viele Arten als Zierpflanzen.

(Au), chemisches Element, Ordnungszahl 79, Atomgewicht 196,97, spezielles Gewicht 19,3, Schmelzpunkt 1064 °C, Siedepunkt 2707 °C. Gelbes, besonders dehn- und walzbares Edelmetall, chemisch resistent.
(Diacetyl-Morphin-Hydrochlorid), suchterzeugendes Rauschgift, Opiumalkaloid.
(Er), chemisches Element aus der Gruppe der Lanthaniden, Ordnungszahl 68, Atomgewicht 167, 26.
(Es), chemisches Element aus der Gruppe der Actiniden, Ordnungszahl 99, Massenzahlen 246, 248-256; benannt nach Albert Einstein.
(Eu), chemisches Element aus der Gruppe der Lanthaniden, Ordnungszahl 63, Atomgewicht 151,96.

(F), chemisches Element, OZ 9, Atomgewicht 18,998, spezifisches Gewicht 1,696, Schmelzpunkt -218 °C, Siedepunkt -188,1 °C. Gelbgrünes, giftiges Gas von stechendem Geruch; Halogen. Sehr reaktionsfähig: Reagiert mit Wasserstoff bereits in Dunkelheit explosionsartig. Vorkommen: Flussspat, Kryolith. Fluorwasserstoff (Flussäure) greift Glas an. Salze: Fluoride, in geringen Mengen in Zahnpasta zur Härtung des Zahnschmelzes. Herstellung durch Elektrolyse aus Salzschmelzen.

(Ga), chemisches Element, Ordnungszahl 31, Atomgewicht 69,72, spezielles Gewicht 5,91, Schmelzpunkt 29,78 °C, Siedepunkt 2403 °C; glänzend weisses metallisches Vorkommen: Zinkblende. Füllmittel für Hochtemperaturthermometer, Wärmeaustauschmittel.
(Ha), künstliches chemisches Element, Ordnungszahl 105; kurzlebiges Isotop, mit der Massenzahl 260 nachgewiesen.
(HCHO), einfachster Aldehyd; stechend riechendes Gas; in wässriger Lösung (Formalin) zur Desinfektion, Konservierung von tierischen Präparaten; gesundheitsschädlich.

(He), chemisches Element aus der Gruppe der Edelgase, Ordnungszahl 2, Atomgewicht 4,003, Siedepunkt -268,9 °Celsius, spezifisches Gewicht 0,178; das am schwersten zu verflüssigende Element; chemisch absolut resistent; Gewinnung aus Erdgas; Verwendung in der Beleuchtungs- und Tieftemperaturtechnik, ferner als Füllgas für Ballons, Thermometer und Lampen.
(Hf), chemisches Element, Ordnungszahl 72, Atomgewicht 178,49; Metall, chemisch sehr ähnlich dem Zirkonium; Herstellung im Extraktions- und Ionenaustauschverfahren; Verwendung in der Kerntechnik.

Österreichischer Komponist, 1732-1809, langjähriger Kapellmeister der Fürsten Esterhazy; eigentlicher Begründer der Wiener Klassik; 1791 Ehrendoktorwürde der Universität Oxford; Schöpfer von 68 klassischen Streichquartetten ("Kaiserquartett"); Sinfonien (107), Kammermusik (unter anderem 39 Klaviertrios, 3 Klavierkonzerte, mehr als 60 Klaviersonaten), 5 Orgelkonzerte, 13 italienische Opern, Oratorien (Die Schöpfung, Die Jahreszeiten), 14 Messen.

(Sanskrit: Swastika = das, was gut ist), glückbringendes Zeichen und Sonnensymbol, in verschiedener Ausformung schon seit der Frühgeschichte belegt und auch in der germanischen Volkskunst üblich. In der Romantik wurde es wiederentdeckt und von der Turnerbewegung zum Zeichen ihres "Bekenntnisses zum deutschen Volkstum" verwendet. Wandervögel und Freikorps schmückten sich damit und gaben ihm den völkisch-antisemitischen Charakter. Der junge Hitler machte mit dem Zeichen in diesem Sinn Bekanntschaft, adaptierte es später für die NSDAP und entwarf persönlich die ··········fahne: "Im Rot sehen wir den sozialen Gedanken der Bewegung, im Weiss den nationalistischen, im ········ die Mission des Kampfes für den Sieg des arischen Menschen."?

entries.question: A bell tower, usually not actually attached to a church.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A continuous aisle in a building, especially around the apse in a church.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A curved structure used to span an opening.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A curved triangle at the corners of a square or polygonal room, used at the opening of a dome.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A cylindrical vertical support usually consisting of a base, shaft and capital.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A flattened, shallow column or pier projecting from a wall. It usually has a base, shaft, and capital but is decorative rather than structural.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A horizontal projection, such as a balcony or beam, supported at one end only.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A method of construction in which vertical beams are used to support a horizontal beam.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A movement that developed in the 1920s, characterized by a regularized surface, a lightening of mass, and  often large expanses of glass.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A multistoried building, typically Asian, forming a tower with upward curving roofs over the individual stories.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A part of a church or a separate building, often octagonal or round, in which baptisms take place.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A passageway of a Christian Church or a Roman basilica running paralell to the nave, separated from it by an arcade or colonnade.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A projecting support built into or against the external wall of a building, typically used in Gothic buildings. A flying  is an arch that transfers the thrust of a vault to a lower support.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A roofed gallery with an open arcade or colonnade on at least one side.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A row of columns, usually equidistant, supporting a beam or entablature.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A row of windows in the upper part of a wall, especially in a church, to admit light below.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A semicircular area at the end of a church; in most churches it contains the altar.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A series of arches supported by columns or piers, or a passageway formed by these arches.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A slender, lofty tower with balconies, attached to a Muslim mosque.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A small structure on top of a dome, tower or roof often open to admit light below.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A spiral scroll used on Ionic and Corinthian capitals.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A spout placed on the roof gutter of a Gothic building to carry away rainwater, usually carved in the shapes of fanciful animals and grotesque beasts.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A square of rectangular area in a church between the apse and the crossing.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A stone slab at the top of a classical column aiding the support of the architecture.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A structure that forms the arms of a cross-shaped church.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A structure usually attached to a building, such as a porch, consisting of a roof supported by piers or columns.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A style of English architecture prevalent from 1485-1558 transitional between Gothic and Palladian, with emphasis on country manors.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A style that emerged in the 1970s characterized by references to and evocations of past architectural styles, particularly the classical tradition. It is frequently colorful and wittily ornamentive.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A style that flourished in the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries, characterized by exuberant decoration, curvaceous forms, and a grand scale generating a sense of movement; later developments within the movement show more restraint.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A tall, tapering, four-sided stone shaft with a pyramidal top.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A tall, tapering, pointed roof on a tower, as in the top of a steeple.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A vaulted roof of circular or polygonal shape.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An arched brick or stone ceiling or roof.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An ornamented canopy over an altar, tomb or throne.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An upright masonry support.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Any important face of a building, usually the principal front with the main entrance.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In German Romanesque, a monumental entrance to a church consisting of towers, with a chapel above.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In a church, the area where the transept and the nave intersect, usually emphasized by a dome or a tower.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In a classical building, the triangular gable between the horizontal entablature and the sloping roof; in general, and architechtural feature over a door or window.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In 1958 the Nobel prize in literature was given to Boris Leonidovich Paternak for his important achievement both in contemporary lyrical poetry and in the field of the great ... ?
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In a roman basilika, the central aisle. In a church, the main section extending from the entrance to the crossing.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In an ancient Roman house, a central room open to the sky, usually having a pool for the collection of rainwater. In churches, a front courtyard.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ancient Assyria and Babylonia, a tower in the shape of a stepped pyramide. It formed the base of a temple.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ancient Roman architecture, a large oblong building, generally with double columns and a semicircular apse at one end. In Christian architecture, a church with a nave, apse, and aisles.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In religious institutions, a courtyard with covered walks.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Moldings and ornamentation projecting from the surface of a wall.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Ornament of ribs, bars, etc. in panels or screens, as in the upper part of a Gothic window.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Stones hewn, squared, and smoothed for use in building, as distinguished from rough building stones.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Sun-dried brick used in places with warm, dry climates, such as Egypt and Mexico; also, the structures built out of these bricks.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The elevated stronghold in ancient Greek cities.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The lowest part of an entablature resting on the capital of a column.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The measurement by which parts of a building are related to one another, for example, the diameter of a column.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The middle part of an entablature, often decorated with sculpture.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The pointed arch used in Gothic architecture.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The story above the cornice of a building.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The style of this school, founded in Germany by Walter Gropius in 1919, emphasizing simplicity, functionalism and craftsmanship.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The transverse entrance hall of a church.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The triangular area between the two sides of two adjacent arches.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The upper horizontal part of a classical order, between a capital and the roof; it consists of the architrave, frieze, and cornice.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The upper part of an entablature, extending beyond the frieze; also, ornamental molding projecting along the top of a building or wall.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Friendship is a single soul, dwelling in ... ?
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A European movement beginning in France. Gothic sculpture emerged c. 1200, Gothic painting later in the thirteenth century. The artworks are characterized by a linear, graceful, elegant style more naturalistic than that which had existed previously in Europe.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A European movement of the late eighteenth to mid-nineteenth century. In reaction to neoclassicism, it focused on emotion over reason, and on spontaneous expression.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A European style developed in France in the late eleventh century. Its sculpture is ornamental, stylized and complex.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A European style of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. Its elegant, balanced works revived the order and harmony of ancient Greek and Roman art.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A Russian abstract movement originated by Malevich c. 1913. It was characterized by flat geometric shapes on plain backgrounds and emphasized the spiritual qualities of pure form.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A decorative art movement that emerged in the late nineteenth century.  Characterized by dense assymmetrical ornamentation in sinuos forms, it is often symbolic and of an erotic nature.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A figurative movement that emerged in the United States and Britain in the late 1960s and 1970s. The subject matter, usually everyday scenes, is portrayed in an extremely detailed, exacting style. It is also called superrealism, especially when referring to sculpture.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A group of American painters who united out of opposition to academic standards in the early twentieth century.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A group of English painters formed in 1848. These artists attempted to recapture the style of painting preceding Raphael. They rejected industrialized England and focused on painting from nature, producing detailed, colorful works.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A late-nineteenth-century French school of painting. It focused on transitory visual impressions, often painted directly from nature, with an emphasis on the changing effects of light and color.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A method of painting developed by Seurat and Signac in the 1880s. It used dabs of pure color that were intended to mix in the eyes of viewers rather than on the canvas. It is also called divisionism or neoimpressionism.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A movement in American painting and sculpture that originated in the late 1950s. It emphasized pure, reduced forms and strict, systematic compositions.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A movement in European painting in the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries, characterized by violent movement, strong emotion, and dramatic lighting and coloring.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A movement of the 1920s and 1930s that began in France. It explored the unconscious, often using images from dreams. It used spontaneous techniques and featured unexpected juxtapositions of objects.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A movement of the 1960s and 1970s that emphasized the artistic idea over the art object. It attempted to free art from the confines of the gallery and the pedestal.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A movement that began in Britain and the United States in the 1950s. It used the images and techniques of mass media, advertising, and popular culture, often in an ironic way.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A movement, c. 1915-23, that rejected accepted aesthetic standards. It aimed to create antiart and nonart, often employing a sense of the absurd.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A painting movement that flourished in France in the 1880s and 1980s in which subject matter was suggested rather than directly presented. It featured decorative, stylized, and evocative images.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A russian abstract movement begun in the early twentieth century. It employs an analytic vision based on fragmentation and multiple viewpoints.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A style, c. 1520-1600, that arose in reaction to the harmony and proportion of the High Renaissance. It featured elongated, contorted poses, crowded canvases, and harsh lighting and coloring.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A technique in abstract painting developed in the 1950s. It focuses on the lyrical effects of large areas of color, often poured or stained onto the canvas.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A termed coined by British art critic Roger Fry to refer to a group of nine-teenth century painters, who were dissatisfied with the limitations of impressionism. It has since been used to refer to various reactions against impressionism, such as fauvism and expressionism.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An abstract movement in Europe and the United States, begun in the mid-1950s, based on the effect of optical patterns.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An eighteenth-century European style, originating in France. In reaction to the grandeur and massiveness of the baroque, it employed refined, elegant, highly decorative forms.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An italian movement c.1909-1919. It attempted to integrate the dynamism of the machine age into art.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Artwork, usually paintings, characterized by a simplified style, nonscientific perspective, and bold colors. The artists are generally not professionally trained.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Design style prevalent during the 1920s and 1930s, characterized by a sleek use of straight lines and slender forms.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: From the Hebrew word for 'prophet'. A group of French painters active in the 1890s who worked in a subjective, sometimes mystical style, stressing flat areas of color and pattern.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: From the french word 'fauve', meaning 'wild beast'. A style adopted by artists associated with Matisse, c. 1905-1908. They painted in a spontaneous manner, using bold colors.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Group of American artists from 1908 to 1918. Their work featured scenes of urban realism.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In a general sense, refers to objective representation. More specifically, a nineteenth century movement, especially in France, that rejected idealized academic styles in favor of everyday subjects.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Meaning 'rebirth' in french. Refers to Europe c. 1400-1600. The style began in Italy and stressed the forms of classical antiquity, a realistic representation of space based on scientific perspective, and secular subjects.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Movement in painting, originating in New York City in the 1940s. It emphasized spontaneous personal expression, freedom from accepted artistic values, surface quallities of paint, and the act of painting itself.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Referring to the principles of Greek and Roman art of antiquity with its emphasis on harmony, proportion, balance, and simplicity. In a general sense, it refers to art based on accepted standards of beauty.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Refers to art that uses emphasis and distortion to communicate emotion. More specifically, it refers to early twentieth-century northern European art, especially in Germany c. 1905-23.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Works of a culturally homogenous people without formal training, generally according to regional traditions and involving crafts.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A band of painted or sculpted decoration, often at the top of a wall.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A composition made of cut and pasted pieces of materials, sometimes with images added by the artist.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A flat board used by a painter to mix and hold colors, traditionally oblong, with a hole for the thumb; also, a range of colors used by a particular painter.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A large painting or decoration done on a wall.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A method of producing images or letters from sheets of cardboard, metal, or other materials from which forms have been cut away.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A method of watercolor painting, but prepared with a more gluey base, producing a less transparent effect.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A painting or drawing executed in a single color.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A painting technique using pigments mixed with egg yolk and water. It produces clear, pure colors.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A print made by carving on a wood block, which is then inked and printed.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A printing process in which ink impressions are taken from a flat stone or metal plate prepared with a greasy substance, such as an oily crayon.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A realistic style of painting in which everyday life forms the subject matter, as distinguished from religious or historical painting.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A representation of a human or an animal form.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A single print made from a metal or glass plate on which an image has been represented in paint, ink, etc.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A soft, subdued color; a drawing stick made of ground pigments, chalk, and gum water.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A technique of engraving, using a sharp-pointed needle, that produces a furrowed edge resulting in a print with soft, velvety lines.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An artwork humoously excaggerating the qualities, defects, or pecularities of a person or idea.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An etching tecnique in which a solution of asphalt or resin is used on the plate. It produces prints with rich, gray tones.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Ground chalk or plaster mixed with glue, used as a base coat for tempera and oil painting.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In painting, a thin layer of translucent color.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In painting, a work made of several panels or scenes joined together. A diptych has two panels; a triptych, three.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In painting, the degree of lightness or darkness in a color.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In sculpting, the cutting of a form from a solid, hard material such as stone or wood, in contrast to the technique of modeling.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In sculpture, the building up of form using a soft medium such as clay or wax, as distinguished from carving. In painting and drawing, using color and lighting variations to produce a three-dimensional effect.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In sculpture, the projection of an image or form from its background. Sculpture formed in this manner is described as high relief or low relief (bas-relief), depending on the degree of projection. In painting or drawing, the apparent projection of parts conveying the illusion of three dimensions.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Meaning 'fool the eye' in french. In painting, the fine, detailed rendering of objects to convey the illusion that the painted forms are real and three-dimensional.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Meaning 'fresh' in italian. The technique of painting on moist lime plaster with colors ground in water.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: On a represented form, a point of most intense light.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Paint applied very thickly. It often projects from the picture surface.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Painting in which natural scenery is the subject.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Reducing or distorting in order to represent three-dimensional space as perceived by the eye, according to the rules of perspective.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The effect of the harmony of color and values in a work.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The rendering of light and shade in painting; the subtle graduations and marked variations of light and shade for dramatic effect.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The representation of inanimate objects in painting, drawing or photography.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The technique of producing printed designs through various methods of incising on wood or metal blocks, which are then inked and printed.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The visual and tactile quality of a work based on the particular way the materials are handled; also, the distribution of tones or shades of a single color.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Water-soluble paint made from pigments and a plastic binder?
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Never confuse motion with ... ?
entries.author: serv

entries.question: I do not sing, I do not dance, and I don't say ... ?
entries.author: serv

entries.question: I am not an actor. I am a ... ?
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Americans usually get it right, after trying ... ?
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The first half of our lives is ruined by our parents, and the second half ... ?
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A Bohemian folk dance in duple time with a hop on the fouth beat. It became a popular ballroom dance in the mid-nineteenth century.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A Japanese dance drama featuring stylized narrative choreographic movements.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A Sevillian gypsy dance, possibly originating in India, also with Moorish and Arabian influences, originally accompanied by songs and clapping and later by the guitar, and characterized by its heelwork.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A Spanish dance in ¾ time or 3/8 time with castanets.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A ballet bow or curtsy in which one foot is pointed in front and the body leans forward.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A ballet in which the women wear white tutus, such as the second and fourth acts of Swan Lake.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A ballet movement in which the dancer repeatedly crosses his or her legs in the air.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A ballet with a plot, usually tragic, to bring dramatic coherence to the performance of ballet.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A basic movement in the technique of Martha Graham, based on breath inhalation and exhalation.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A beating movement of the legs.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A bending of the knees in any of the five positions.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A dance for two, usually a woman and a man. In its traditional form, it begins with an entreé and adagio, followed by solo variations for each dancer, and a coda.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A dance with a fast or moderate tempo.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A grave, processional court dance popular in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A jump in which the legs open in second position in the air, resembling a scissors.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A leap from one leg to the other in which one leg is thrown to the side, front or back.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A lively Spanish dance in triple time performed with castanets or tambourines.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A lively social dance popular during the 1930s; it originated at the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem in 1928, where it was known as the Lindy.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A male dancer who performs the 'princely' roles of the classical ballet, such as the Prince in Swan Lake.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A plotless work composed of pure dance movements, although the composition may suggest a mood or subject.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A polish national dance in triple time with an accent on the second beat, characterized by proud bearing, clicking of heels, and holubria, a special turning step.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A position on the tip of the toes.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A series of small, fast steps executed with the feet very close together.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A sliding step in which one foot 'chases' and displaces the other.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A slow and graceful dance, the most popular dance of the eighteenth century, characterized by symmetrical figures and elaborate curtsys and bows.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A social dance in ¾ time that became widely popular in the nineteenth century. It developed from the Landler, a German-Austrian turning dance.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A social dance in ¾ time, which after originating in Spain, developed in Argentina, where it was influenced by black dance style and rhytm.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A social dance of American origin in duple time.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A social dance popular in the nineteenth century. It was a square dance in five sections, each in a different time.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A solemn court dance usually in duple time, popular in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A spectacular movement in which the dancer propels himself or herself around a supporting leg with rapid movements of the other leg while remaining in a fixed spot.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A step that rocks from one foot to the other, usually in ¾ time.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A turn on one leg, with the toe of the other leg touching the knee of the turning leg.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: A turn while jumping straight up in the air.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An American folk dance with an even number of couples forming a square, two lines, or a circle. The dance is comprised of figures announced by a caller.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An English folk dance that appeared in the fifteenth century, in which dancers wore bells on their legs and characters included a fool, a boy on a hobby horse, and a main in blackface.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An african-american dance in which couples strut and compete with high kicks and fast steps.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: An unfolding of the leg in the air.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Any dance to slow music; also, part of the classical pas-de-deux in ballet.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Any solo performance in a ballet.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Catlike leap in which one foot follows the other into the air, knees bent; the landing is in the fifth position.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a bend from the waist to the side or to the back.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a closed position of the feet.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a gliding step which usually connects two steps.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a jump from one to both feet, usually landing in fifth position.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a jump off one foot that is 'broken' by a beating of the legs in the air.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a leap in which the lower leg beats against the upper one at an angle, before the dancer lands again on the lower leg.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a lowering of the body by bending the knee.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a pose in which one leg is raised in back or in front with knee bent, usually with one arm raised.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a position of the arms above the head.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a position of the body at an oblique angle and partly hidden.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a position with one leg extended at an oblique angle while the body is also at an oblique angle.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a position with the body at an oblique angle and the working leg crossing the line of the body.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a rising with a spring movement to point or demi-point.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In ballet, a slow turn of the body on the whole foot.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... 's distinctive and controversial brand of pragmatism expresses itself along two main axes. One is negative---a critical diagnosis of what he takes to be defining projects of modern philosophy. The other is positive---an attempt to show what intellectual culture might look like, once we free ourselves from the governing metaphors of mind and knowledge in which the traditional problems of epistemology and metaphysics (and indeed, in his view, the self-conception of modern philosophy) are rooted.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... asserts the relativity of morality
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... asserts the relativity of truth.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... can be defined as an abstract object or term which ranges over particular things. The classic problem involves whether abstract objects such as "largeness" exist in a realm independent of human thought. Realists argue that they do.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... can be thought of as the metaphysical theory that attempts to account for the truth of claims like 'It is possible that there are Aliens' without appealing to any nonactual objects whatsoever. What makes this theory so philosophically interesting, is that there is no obviously correct way to account for the truth of claims like 'It is possible that there are Aliens' without appealing to possible but nonactual objects.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... denied the soundness of metaphysics and traditional philosophy; they asserted that many philosophical problems are indeed meaningless. During 1930s the most important representatives emigrated to USA, where they influenced American philosophy. Until 1950s it was the leading philosophy of science; today its influence persists especially in the way of doing philosophy, in the great attention given to the analysis of scientific thought and in the definitely acquired results of the technical researches on formal logic and the theory of probability.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... denotes any metaphysical theory which claims that reality consists of a multiplicity of distinct, fundamental entities. The term was first used by Christian Wolff (1679-1754), and later popularized by William James in The Will to Believe. It is distinguished from both monism, the view that one kind of thing exists, and dualism, the view that two kinds of things exist.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... entails that the individual self is either the motivating moral force and is, or should, be the end of moral action.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... have sought to deflate the universal pretensions of liberal theory. The main target has been Rawls description of the original position as an 'Archemedian point' from which the structure of a social system can be appraised, a position whose special virtue is that it allows us to regard the human condition 'from the perspective of eternity', from all social and temporal points of view.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... having studied science at the University of Vienna, moved into philosophy for his doctoral thesis, made a name for himself both as an expositor and (later) as a critic of Karl Popper's 'critical rationalism', and went on to become one of this century's most famous philosophers of science. An imaginative maverick, he became a critic of philosophy of science itself, particularly of 'rationalist' attempts to lay down or discover rules of scientific method.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is a formulation utilitarianism which maintains that a behavioral code or rule is morally right if the consequences of adopting that rule are more favorable than unfavorable to everyone. It is contrasted with act utilitarianism which maintains that the morality of each action is to be determined in relation to the favorable or unfavorable consequences that emerge from that action.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is a movement in cognitive science which hopes to explain human intellectual abilities using artificial neural networks (also known as 'neural networks' or 'neural nets'). Neural networks are simplified models of the brain composed of large numbers of units (the analogs of neurons) together with weights that measure the strength of connections between the units. These weights model the effects of the synapses that link one neuron to another. Experiments on models of this kind have demonstrated an ability to learn such skills as face recognition, reading, and the detection of simple grammatical structure.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is a name given to a group of ancient philosophers who, from the existing philosophical beliefs, tried to select the doctrines that seemed to them most reasonable, and out of these constructed a new system
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is a philosophical position maintaining that our minds gain knowledge independently of experience through innate ideas or mental faculties.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is a term used in both ethics and epistemology. In ethics it deals with determining right actions and appropriate beliefs. In epistemology, it is the central component to knowledge as justified true belief.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is a term used to identify a type of knowledge which is obtained independently of experience.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is a theory in the philosophy of mind which maintains that talk of mental events should be translated into talk about observable behavior.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is an epistemological position that we do not have knowledge or justification for believing in objective moral principles. It does not involve the rejection of moral values themselves, but simply the denial that we have knowledge of an objective realm of morals
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is defined as the complex method of obtaining information about our surrounding world, specifically through our senses, and apprehending this information as beliefs.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is sometimes identified (usually by its critics) as the thesis that all points of view are equally valid. In ethics, this amounts to saying that all moralities are equally good; in epistemology it implies that all beliefs, or belief systems, are equally true.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is the belief that all values are baseless and that nothing can be known or communicated. It is often associated with extreme pessimism and a radical skepticism that condemns existence.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is the description and study of appearances. The term has come to be closely associated with the method of inquiry that was originated by Brentano and further developed by Husserl. The movement originally placed an emphasis on human experience descriptions, as the human experience was directed onto objects.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is the idea, often associated with the political theories of John Locke and the "founders" of the American republic, that government can and should be legally limited in its powers, and that its authority depends on its observing these limitations.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is the position that arises out of the difficulties present in the dualism between the phenomenon and the object. It maintains that all we know are phenomena; we know nothing of the external things causing the phenomena.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is the theory that God or the ultimate nature of reality is to be conceived as some form of will (or conation). This theory is contrasted to intellectualism, which gives primacy to God's reason.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is the view that moral principles have an objective foundation, and are not based on subjective human convention.The term in its broadest sense, applies to moral theories that emphasize the use of reason or a rational procedure in moral decision making.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... is the view that moral utterances are neither true nor false statements about the world. They are, instead, expressions of feelings or prescriptive utterances. The key to this issue is distinguishing between two types of utterances: (1) propositional utterances, and (2) nonpropositional utterances.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... lived at a critical juncture of western culture when the arrival of the Aristotelian corpus in Latin translation reopened the question of the relation between faith and reason, calling into question the modus vivendi that had obtained for centuries. This crisis flared up just as universities were being founded.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... maintained that knowledge comes from foundational concepts known intuitively through reason, such as innate ideas. Other concepts are then deductively drawn from these.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... names both a political theory of the legitimacy of political authority and a moral theory about the origin and/or legitimate content of moral norms. The political theory of authority claims that legitimate authority of government must derive from the consent of the governed, where the form and content of this consent derives from the idea of contract or mutual agreement. The moral theory of (this theory) claims that moral norms derive their normative force from the idea of contract or mutual agreement and is thus skeptical of the possibility of grounding morality or political authority in either divine will or some perfectionist ideal of the nature of humanity.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... refers to a class of normative moral theories which maintain that an action is morally right if the consequences of that action are more favorable than unfavorable. Thus, correct moral conduct is determined solely by a cost-benefit analysis of an action's consequences.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... refers to the 18th century philosophical movement in Great Britain which maintained that all knowledge comes from experience
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... refers to the view that the truth of a thing is independent from the observing subject. The notion entails that certain things exist independently from the mind, or that they are at least in an external sphere.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... traditionally refers to a 17th century philosophical movement begun by Descartes. After Descartes, several dozen scientists and philosophers continued his teachings throughout continental Europe and, accordingly were titled "Cartesians." Some Cartesians strayed little from Descartes' scientific and metaphysical theories. Others incorporated his theories into Calvinistic theology. But a handful of philosophers influenced by Descartes were more original in developing their own views and these people are included under this more more general title.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ... was a profound and prolific writer in the Danish "golden age" of intellectual and artistic activity. His work crosses the boundaries of philosophy, theology, psychology, literary criticism, devotional literature and fiction. Kierkegaard brought this potent mixture of discourses to bear as social critique and for the purpose of renewing Christian faith within Christendom. At the same time he made many original conceptual contributions to each of the disciplines he employed. He is known as the "father of existentialism", but at least as important are his critiques of Hegel and of the German romantics, his contributions to the development of modernism, his literary experimentation, his vivid re-presentation of biblical figures to bring out their modern relevance, his invention of key concepts which have been explored and redeployed by thinkers ever since, his interventions in contemporary Danish church politics, and his fervent attempts to analyse and revitalise Christian faith.

... was the founder of American pragmatism (which he called "pragmaticism"), an extender of the Scotistic theory of signs (which he called "semeiotic"), an extraordinarily prolific logician and mathematician, and a developer of an evolutionary, psycho-physically monistic metaphysical system. A practicing chemist and geodesist by profession, he nevertheless considered scientific philosophy, and especially logic, to be his vocation. In the course of his polymathic researches, he wrote on a wide range of topics, ranging from mathematical logic to psychology.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: ..., British philosopher, economist, moral and political theorist, and administrator, was the most influential English-speaking philosopher of the nineteenth century. His views are of continuing significance, and are generally recognized to be among the deepest and certainly the most effective defenses of empiricism and of a liberal political view of society and culture. The overall aim of his philosophy is to develop a positive view of the universe and the place of humans in it, one which contributes to the progress of human knowledge, individual freedom and human well-being. His views are not entirely original, having their roots in the British empiricism of John Locke, George Berkeley and David Hume, and in the utilitarianism of Jeremy Bentham. But he gave them a new depth, and his formulations were sufficiently articulate to gain for them a continuing influence among a broad public.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Along with J. G. Fichte and F. W. J. Schelling, ... belongs to the period of "German idealism" in the decades following Kant. The most systematic of the post-Kantian idealists, he attempted, throughout his published writings as well as in his lectures, to elaborate a comprehensive and systematic ontology from a "logical" starting point. He is perhaps most well-known for his teleological account of history, an account which was later taken over by Marx and "inverted" into a materialist theory of an historical development culminating in communism.

An ... may be defined as an object that has been intentionally made or produced for a certain purpose. Often the word is used in a more restricted sense to refer to simple, hand-made objects (for example, tools) which represent a particular culture. (This might be termed the 'archaeological sense' of the word.) In experimental science, the expression is sometimes used to refer to experimental results which are not manifestations of the natural phenomena under investigation, but are due to the particular experimental arrangement.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Generally regarded as the most important philosopher ever to write in English,  the last of the great triumvirate of "British empiricists", ... was also noted as an historian and essayist. A master stylist in any genre, his major philosophical works remain widely and deeply influential, despite their being denounced by many of his contemporaries as works of scepticism and atheism. While Hume's influence is evident in the moral philosophy and economic writings of his close friend Adam Smith, he also awakened Immanuel Kant from his "dogmatic slumbers" and "caused the scales to fall" from Jeremy Bentham's eyes. Charles Darwin counted him as a central influence, as did "Darwin's bulldog," Thomas Henry Huxley
entries.author: serv

entries.question: In its most general philosophical sense, a ... involves any object in the world around us that we perceive through our senses. It is that perception of an object which becomes visible to our consciousness.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: Philosophers are interested in a constellation of issues involving the concept of truth. A preliminary issue, although somewhat subsidiary, is to decide what sorts of things can be true. Is truth a property of sentences (which are linguistic entities in some language or other), or is truth a property of propositions (nonlinguistic, abstract and timeless entities)? The principal issue is: What is truth? It is the problem of being clear about what you are saying when you say some claim or other is true. The most important theories of truth are the ... ?
entries.answer: Correspondence Theory, the Semantic Theory, the Deflationary Theory, the Coherence Theory and the Pragmatic Theory
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The ... theory claims that we perceive something called ... in place of the actual objects that are in the world around us. This concept was first introduced by Moore, and was later adopted by Russell and Broad. This theory has come under scrutiny from Ryle and Austin, who propose that the notion of ... only complicates our account of perceptions. We do not perceive discrete bits of information, but instead perceive objects in our surrounding world
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The concept of ... is that all derived or secondary things proceed or flow from the more primary. It is distinguished from the doctrine of creation by its elimination of a definite will in the first cause, from which all things are made to emanate according to natural laws and without conscious volition. It differs from the theory of formation at the hands of a supreme artisan who finds his matter ready to his hand, in teaching that all things, whether actually or only apparently material, flow from the primal principle.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The exact point in time when the term ... was first adopted is unknown. It is, qhowever, certain that Italy and the re-adopting of Latin letters as the staple of human culture were responsible for the name of Humanists. Literoe humaniores was an expression coined in reference to the classic literature of Rome and the imitation and reproduction of its literary forms in the new learning; this was in contrast to and against the Literoe sacroe of scholasticism.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The field of ethics, also called moral philosophy, involves systematizing, defending, and recommending concepts of right and wrong behavior. Philosophers today usually divide ethical theories into three general subject areas, ... ?
entries.answer: metaethics, normative ethics and applied ethics
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The term ... is ambiguous. It refers to a type of moral theory, as well as to a type of legal theory, despite the fact that the core claims of the two kinds of theory are logically independent.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The term ... refers to information obtained externally by means of the senses or internally through emotion. The term a posteriori is often used interchangeably.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The term ... was first used by Christian Wolff in his discussions of the mind-body problem to depict both philosophers who would only acknowledge the mind (idealism or mentalism) and philosophers who only acknowledged the body (materialism). The meaning Wolff originally intended by using the term has broadened in scope through the centuries, and today applies to any doctrine or theory that claims that all things, no matter how many or of what variety, can be reduced to one unified thing in time, space, or quality.
entries.author: serv

entries.question: The term ... was originally coined by Thomas Hyde around the beginning of the eighteenth century. As a metaphysical theory, it states that the world is made up of two elemental categories which are incommensurable. This includes distinctions between mind and body, good and evil, universal and particular, and phenomena and noumena.
